title: Cambodia, Thailand ink ceasefire deal to end weeks of fighting | ABC NEWS
description: Thailand and Cambodia have signed a new ceasefire agreement to end weeks of border clashes, which killed at least 100 and displaced thousands.  The 72-hour truce forbids further military movement and violations of airspace for military purposes by either side.  Under the agreement, Bangkok will release 18 Cambodian soldiers it has held since earlier border skirmishes in July. title: Who is and isn't running in Myanmarâ€™s election? | ABC NEWS
description: Polls have opened in Myanmar for the first general election in five years, overseen by the military government amid a civil war. The National League for Democracy (NLD), led by Nobel laureate Aung San Suu Kyi, is banned from participating. In the last election, the NLD won by a landslide, but the military staged a coup shortly after the results were announced. title: Voters in war-torn Myanmar trickle in to 'sham' election | ABC NEWS
description: Five years after a military coup overthrew Myanmar's democratically elected government and ignited a civil war, the country is holding elections that many view as a sham. Human rights activists are calling for a voter boycott. Voter turnout is significantly lower than in the last election, when the National League for Democracy, led by Nobel laureate Aung San Suu Kyi, won decisively before the military staged a coup.  ABC Asia editor Karishma Vyas reports that locals are hesitant to speak to reporters, and the team has been followed during its coverage. title: Critical and rare earth minerals explained using a house | ABC NEWS
description: Surviving the day without critical minerals is practically impossible in the modern world.  A hundred years ago, society was reliant on about a dozen main metals. Now nearly the entire periodic table is needed to sustain our daily lives.  Rare earths have become a hot commodity, used as a bargaining chip in Donald Trumpâ€™s tariff wars, exposing supply chain vulnerabilities and highlighting Chinaâ€™s upper hand.  With mind-boggling names such as praseodymium, dysprosium, and ytterbium â€” not to be mistaken for yttrium â€” it can be easy to glaze over.  But due to critical mineralsâ€™ essential role in technologies, economies and national security, these elements will continue to demand attention.  So to truly understand just how critical these minerals have become, letâ€™s take a tour around the house.  By Annika Burgess with illustrations by Sharon Gordon for ABC News Digital.
